NewsLine.NewsLineText: ECONOMY-ISRAEL-FUNDING (RPT):RPT-INTERVIEW-Overseas Jewish funding boosts Israeli coffers

body.p: JERUSALEM, Sept 23 (Reuters) - Jews around the world, backing Israel as it battles a Palestinian insurgency, are set to buy record amounts of special state bonds at relatively low interest rates this year to help ease its economic woes.

A Finance Ministry official said on Monday the purchases could reach a record $1.35 billion and as a result the country may not have to tap conventional international markets to finance its debt requirements later this year as planned.

Eldad Fresher, senior deputy accountant-general, said Israel's plan was to raise $1 billion from private State of Israel bonds -- typically bought by Jews around the world as a way of showing support for Israel -- and another $900 million in two bond offerings to institutional investors.
Moody's Investors Service rates Israel A2, compared with A- from both Standard & Poor's and Fitch Ratings.

Israel earlier this year sold 400 million euros in bonds and was set to sell another $500 million in the fourth quarter but sales of State of Israel bonds have already hit $1.1 billion and looks to shatter its record high of $1.2 billion in 1991.
"State of Israel bonds are selling much more than expected," Fresher told Reuters, noting those bonds bear lower interest rates than bonds sold on the market.
"This is the cheapest way we can raise money," he said.

Five-year State of Israel bonds, sold in Jewish communities around the world, sell for 140 basis points above the five-year U.S. Treasury yield, which is currently at 2.76 percent. Ten-year Israel bonds sell for 165 basis points above 10-year Treasuries, currently 3.71 percent.

"The Jewish diaspora is raising more money at more attractive terms," Fresher said. "Institutional investors tend to be very sensitive to current events and to the security situation but the Jewish diaspora is indifferent to the security situation and even the contrary."

For years, Jewish communities around the world have shown support for Israel by buying bonds, diminishing the country's need to tap the open market. With Israel coming under attack from a wave of Palestinian suicide bombings and a perception among many Jews of a rise in anti-Semitism and anti-Israel rhetoric, Jews seemed to open their pockets this year more than in past years.

Israel needs the financing more than ever since it is mired in its worst recession in 50 years due to a global economic downturn and bloody two-year Palestinian uprising. Government spending has been slashed numerous times this year as it tries to keep the budget deficit under control due to a plunge in tax revenues and jump in defence costs.
"It is the ultimate avenue to use in bad times," Fresher said of the private funding. "We anticipate State of Israel bonds will raise at least $1.25 billion and it can easily reach $1.35 billion."

In 2001, $1.0 billion was raised by State of Israel bonds. Most of the funds are typically raised in the United States. In New York, which has the largest overseas Jewish population, synagogues organise regular bond breakfasts and dinners.

Fresher noted 2002 was shaping up to be the best year since 1991, the year Israel was hit by Iraqi scud missiles during the Gulf war and when Israel absorbed some 400,000 immigrants -- mostly from the former Soviet Union.

Still, Fresher would not rule out an issue of dollar-denominated bonds later this year. He said ministry officials will meet in the next couple of weeks with its lead managers Lehman Brothers and Salomon Smith Barney in New York.

"We will see what kind of environment we are facing and what attitude institutional investors have toward an Israeli offering," Fresher said. "State of Israel bonds are doing better than expected so that could cover most of our shortfall.
"If we do have a transaction, it can be from a strategic or tactical point of view because we don't need the money."
